title: СРПСКА НАРОДНА ПЕСМА У МЕТОДИЧКОМ ПРИСТУПУ НАСТАВИ ПОЧЕТНОГ МУЗИЧКОГ ОПИСМЕЊАВАЊА ДР ЗОРИСЛАВЕ ВАСИЉЕВИЋ
summary: Сажетак: Др Зорислава Васиљевић (1932-2009) свој методички приступ настави почетног музичког описмењавања у великој мери је заснивала на коришћењу народних песама/модела. Њихова примена је најзаступљенија у оквиру рада на мелодици-при поставци основних тонова као и у процесу рада на настави ритма. Зорислава Васиљевић је сматрала да се употребом народних песама и песама-модела у оквиру наставе солфеђа ученицима између осталог, поставља база за разумевање српске музичке традиције. Њиховим коришћењем у настави почетног музичког описмењавања она је дала допринос очувању српског националног и културног идентитета. Кључне ријечи: Зорислава Васиљевић, народна песма, настава солфеђа, почетно музичко описмењавање, методички приступ.

summary: The purpose of this study was to examine the effect of motivation on upper-grade elementary students’ preferences for acoustic or tablet-based instruments. title: Igbo Speech Surrogacy: Preliminary Findings Based on the Oja Flute
summary: This research report presents analyses of recordings from the Ìgbò culture of southeastern Nigeria of an ọ̀jà flute player, a female speaker, and a male speaker. After a prepared performance, the participants completed two tasks: (1) mapping speech to flute playing and (2) identifying phrases played on the flute. Contour analysis is applied to annotated recordings to study the mapping of speech tone and rhythm from voice to instrument in parallel utterances by the three participants (male, female, and flute). Response time between the flute playing and spoken phrase identification indicates each prompt’s relative clarity. Using a limited but not predetermined inventory of related praise epithets, participants successfully converted speech to music and music to speech. In the conversion of speech to music, we found that declination was not part of the mapping, indicating it is a phonetic artifact of speech and does not carry a functional load. In identifying surrogate phrases played ...

ARTISTIC DESIGN FEATURES OF ORIENTAL STRING INSTRUMENTS
summary:
In the article the laconic information about the artistic design
features of stringed instruments among Oriental musical instruments is given, it is
also said about their structure and patterning features. The artistic structure of
many musical instruments such as “tar”, “ganun”, “ud”, “dambur”, “kamancha”,
“saz” was explained and the brief analyzes are carried out on the samples to
explain the theme. The information about the musical instruments such as “tar”,
“ganun”, “ud” and “kaman” increased mainly the interest to the article.

title: Tendre ses cordes à l'écoute du monde. Trajectoire artistique et migratoire d’Adama Koeta (Burkina Faso, France, Suisse)
summary: Cet article retrace la trajectoire artistique de l’instrumentiste burkinabè Adama Koeta dans le but d’appréhender les expériences, les rencontres et les acquis qui ont nourri son développement créatif. À travers l’analyse de son cheminement de formation dans la pratique des harpes-luth (kamalengoni, kora), de ses multiples engagements professionnels et des réseaux qu’il mobilise au Burkina Faso, en France et en Suisse, il s’agira d’identifier les ressorts ordinaires et inédits qui meuvent l’activité artistique dans une dynamique translocale. L’approche biographique permettra de relever l’aspect singulier du parcours migratoire d’Adama tout en faisant transparaître les contours des mondes de l’art dans lesquels une bonne partie des musiciens ouest-africains évoluent.

title: The Local Wisdom of Batam Malay Culture
summary: Batam as a metropolitan city which has several places such as old villages, the beaches, barelang, aesthetic building and others that still adhere to local Malay wisdom. Batam is the largest city in the province of Riau Islands, Indonesia. Batam is also known as a tourist destination city which often hosts cultural festivals. The areas of Batam city consist of Batam Island, Rempang Island, Galang Island, and other small islands. It is located in the Singapore Strait and Malacca Straits highlight the cultural diversity in Indonesia. In accordance with the motto of the Indonesian people, namely Bhinneka Tunggal Ika, a festival becomes a medium of cultural learning that is easier for the younger generation to digest. Festival in batam is like festival of malay art kenduri, festival of batam international culture carnival and the others. Generally, cultural festivals are held at certain moments. But now because there is covid-19, the festival is no longer held until the pandemic is subsides or dissapear. Even the festival seldom conducts, there are still many tourism places and some unique activities in batam which make the tourists take the time to visit Batam. Batam also is a stopover place for immigrant and foreigners who want to go to the singapore or malaysia. So it is not only malay culture that has in batam but also there are additional diverse cultures.

research_interests.name: The City in Literature and Culture

title: South African Popular Music
summary: African popular music with analysis about singer Sho Madjozi

title: How We Got into Drum Circles, and How to Get Out: De-Essentializing African Music
summary: Babatunde Ọlátúnjí’s Drums of Passion (1960) caught the attention of prominent American musicians from John Coltrane to the Grateful Dead and turned on subsequent generations to West African djembe drumming. The inclusion of djembe drum circles in education is alarming because they are “based on the partial appropriation and transformation” of African-based drumming. This article suggests how to get out of drum circles by recognizing and embracing African melody, especially pitched idiophones and ensemble singing. We describe a program at two Historically Black Colleges that combines more equitable and accurate representation of African cultures with technological literacy and a greater range of learning modalities.

title: Musicas do mundo em processos educativos
How We Got into Drum Circles, and How to Get Out: De-Essentializing African Music
Coladera Crioula de Sao Bento Partitura Flauta e Piano Educacao Musical Jose Galvao
summary:
Antes de falar sobre a Coladera ou Koladera (em crioulo cabo verdiano) importa referir que este estilo/género musical, genuíno de cabo-verde, é descendente da Morna e que a Morna foi proclamada Património Cultural Imaterial da Humanidade pela UNESCO a 11 de dezembro de 2019. 
Musicalmente falando, a coladeira caracteriza-se por ter um andamento variável entre o allegro e o andante, (o dobro da Morna) e, normalmente, está escrita no compasso binário ou quaternário. A sua estrutura harmónica é baseada no ciclo de quintas (também herança da morna) mas também pode aparecer numa forma simples (tónica/dominante).
Quase sempre monotónica, (composta apenas numa tonalidade) e com uma temática (novamente à semelhança da Morna) que reflete a realidade insular do povo de Cabo Verde, nomeadamente o romantismo dos seus trovadores e o amor à terra (ter de partir e querer ficar). 
Música do mundo – Coladera – Cabo-Verde

research_interests.name: Etnomusicología, Músicas del mundo, Músicas indígenas, Perspectivismo y Ontología indígena, Música del Amazonas

title: World music: a global journey
Love nwantiti CKay ft El Grande Toto Partitura Educacao Musical Jose Galvao
summary:
Love Nwantiti é uma canção do cantor e compositor nigeriano CKay. Em 2021, a música bateu records e chegou aos Tops nos rankings da Europa, Austrália, América Latina e Nova Zelândia, alcançando também o primeiro lugar na Índia e ganhando uma gigantesta popularidade na rede social Tik Tok.
Com uma harmonia baseada em apenas 4 acordes rotativos o tema acaba por ser viciante. Também o ritmo do tema é contagiante e convida à dança e à criação de coreografias e danças de grupo.
A nível melódico o tema tem notas de duração muito curta e o original está numa tonalidade difícil para a flauta de bisel. Por estes motivos simplifiquei a linha melódica, começando por alterar a tonalidade para Ré menor (apenas uma nota alterada na armação de clave, sib) e também simplifiquei a melodia quer ao nível da altura das notas (retirando algumas) quer ao nível do seu ritmo evitando as figuras rítmicas mais curtas (semicolcheias) e substituindo-as por outras mais longas (colcheias e semínimas).

title: Sampling of tradition: Spectres of the past in Serbian hip-hop
Músicas do Mundo em Processos Educativos
summary: Reflexing on intercultural Musical Education, this work discusses issues related to the musical cultures of the world, including themes such as identity, authenticity, decolonialism, among other. Describes three projects that deal with the presence of World Music in Education: for children (Teca Oficina de Música), for young people (Ethno) and for adults (A Magnífica Orchestra Paulistana de Músicas do Mundo) concluding that the world music is  very attractive material bringing changes and  denormalizing the hegemonic repertoire.

title: Ezio Pinza and his Romagna by Roberta Paganelli
summary: I recently translated this article by Roberta Paganelli on the great Italian bass Ezio Pinza for the British periodical "The Record Collector" (https://therecordcollector.org/).

title: Selections from the "Cowboy and the Yogi: Ideals shared by India and America"
summary: India, like America, is a country that nourishes creative individuality. Just as Americans have been inspired by the archetype of the Cowboy, who wanders the open spaces in search of a dream, so Indians are inspired by the Yogi, who wanders inner spaces in search of realization. The essential difference between the two cultures is that Americans demand freedom from rules, and India is a country with lots of rules—that everybody breaks. Indians praise obedience to tradition, but when push comes to shove, it is always the inner voice of intuition that wins out—an intuition that, at its best, inspires each individual to preserve the essence of the tradition as he or she changes it.

title: [Preprint] How We Got into Drum Circles, and How to Get Out: De-essentializing African Music
summary: Babatunde Ọlátúnjí’s 1960 album Drums of Passion caught the attention of prominent American musicians from John Coltrane to the Grateful Dead and turned on subsequent generations to West African djembe drumming. The inclusion of djembe drum circles in education is alarming because they are “based on the partial appropriation and transformation” of African-based drumming (Charry 2005). This essay suggests how to get out of drum circles by recognizing and embracing African melody, especially pitched idiophones and ensemble singing. We describe a program at two Historically Black Colleges that combines more equitable and accurate representation of African cultures with technological literacy and a greater range of learning modalities.

title: L'étiquette « Musiques du monde » : perte ou enrichissement?
summary: Si on peut certainement qualifier l’apport de la world music à l’industrie musicale comme un enrichissement, il y a tout de même lieu de se questionner sur ce que sa présence révèle sur la vision du monde de ceux qui la produisent et la consomment.

title: Our stories, from us the 'they' - Nick Gold talks to Lucy Durán about the making of Buena Vista Social Club
summary:
The remarkable success of Buena Vista Social Club, released by the UK independent label World Circuit, has made it a focus in much of the literature on Cuban popular music of the 1990s and its representation by the world music industry. This article responds to some of the sweeping generalisations in this literature about the kinds of thought processes, strategies and motives that might have led to the production of the album. In those analyses, one voice is conspicuously absent – that of Nick Gold, the owner of World Circuit and the person who made the album happen. Here, in conversation with Lucy Durán, Gold tells the story of Buena Vista in his own words, revealing a tale of collaborative effort, creativity, generosity of spirit and spontaneity. The article questions the methodology of writers who feel they can speak for the views and attitudes of record producers without consulting or interviewing them directly, arguing for more communication between academics and the creative industries. In addition to giving an insider’s view on how one of the best selling world music albums of all time was put together, this article is also a contribution to the budding literature on record production as a ‘new academic field’. 

Keywords: world music; Buena Vista Social Club; Nick Gold; Ry Cooder; Cuban popular music; music production

title: Tradicijska i popularna kultura na muzičkom festivalu Guča
summary:
The characteristics of culture and culture identity of some community can be seen by observing its music tradition (what is perceived as music tradition and which aspects it possess), as well as an attitude toward that tradition, meanings that are ascribed to it, and the context in which it is presented. On the other hand, popular culture is, in some way, a 'contemporary', 'new' culture which modifies or even suppress some segments of traditional culture, but it can also eventually become a part of traditional culture itself. The polarity 'traditional' – 'popular' has gradually lost its clear borders (among other things, traditional has become popular and vice versa), and hence this problematic demands new theoretical approaches nowadays. A complex problematic of the relationship between popular and traditional culture is perceived at the example of music festival Guča (Dragačevo Trumpeters Assembly), held in a small town Guča in the Western part of Serbia. The Guča was launched in the sixties, from the need for preservation of a specific part of traditional folk culture – wind brass folk music, characteristic for some parts of Serbia. A traditional folk nucleus of the Guča has been preserved in its essence until today, but the influences of popular culture have been gradually modified character and content of the festival. Therefore, traditional culture has been transformed into neo-folk culture during the seventies and eighties, while in the nineties the Festival’s programs became under the strong influence of Serbian ‘estrada’. The structure of the audience has been changed, too. While in the sixties the Guča had strongly local character and was appealing only for older inhabitants of villages, in the next 3 decades it became more and more interesting for different kinds of people from all over Yugoslavia. Finally, in the 21st century, Guča has gained wide international popularity and become one of the favorite tourist destinations for young people. Dialogues between traditional and popular culture have been intensified and resulted not only in diverse hybrid cultural and musical phenomena but also in commercialization and internationalization of the Guča.
Keywords: culture, traditional, popular, festival

title: Fado Internacional. Una visión.
summary: El texto a continuación es el capítulo tercero y sexto del libro "Unos españoles en la Corte del Rey Fado", (ISBN: 978-989-8661-66-1)publicado en la editorial lisboeta DG Edições. La autoría del mismo es de Miguel Á. Fernández Fernández, y el libro tiene, además los siguientes autores: Ángel García Prieto y una colaboración de socios y simpatizantes de la Asociación de Amigos del Fado de Asturias (España). El libro es una revisión y actualización del libro "Lisboa, desde el Fado a la Vida", de la misma editorial y cuyos autores son, Ángel García Prieto, Miguel Á. Fernández Fernández, Carmen Brañanova y Natacha Larchier, que fue el primer libro divulgativo sobre el Fado escrito por autores españoles. En dicho capítulo, se analizan, desde un punto de vista internacional y personal, la importancia del Fado y se analizan algunos aspectos que ayudan a entender y vivir la música de Lisboa.

title: Музыкальное востоковедение - одно из новых направлений российской гуманитарной науки
summary:
In this article music Oriental studies as a new direction in the Russian humanities is considered from the point of view of specifying the subject of research, new methodology and its interrelation with classical Oriental studies, ethnomusicology, and other disciplines. Besides, the author pays attention to preconditions and reasons for Russian music Oriental studies formation and reveals centers of its development, and problems in the field of education. 

В статье рассматривается музыкальное востоковедение как новое направление российской науки с точки зрения уточнения собственного предмета исследования, новой методологии и взаимосвязи с классическим востоковедением, этномузыкознанием и другими дисциплинами. Кроме того, автор останавливается на предпосылках и причинах формирования музыкального востоковедения в России, выявляя центры его развития и проблемы в области образования.

title: Motivation and Preference for Acoustic or Tablet- Based Musical Instruments: Comparing Guitars and Gayageums
summary:
The purpose of this study was to examine the effect of motivation on upper-grade elementary students’ preferences for acoustic or tablet-based instruments. The effect of cultural familiarity on musical instrument preference was also investigated.
Participants (N = 138) were classified by motivation levels (low, medium-low, medium-high, and high) and played the guitar, tablet-based guitar, gayageum (Korean string instrument), and tablet-based gayageum. After playing each instrument, participants
rated preferences and provided their reasons. Results of the mixed-model ANOVA revealed two significant main effects for instrumental mode (acoustic vs. tablet-based) and motivation on instrument preference. A significant three-way interaction was
also found: Cultural Familiarity × Mode × Motivation. The two main effects of mode and motivation produced a general pattern in instrument preference: (a) Students generally preferred acoustic instruments to tablet-based instruments, and (b) the
level of motivation was associated with the degree of preference ratings. However, the interaction effect deviated from the general pattern; the low motivation group participants’ preference ratings between acoustic and tablet-based guitars were not significantly different. This deviation from the general pattern appeared only for the culturally familiar instrument (guitar) but not the culturally unfamiliar instrument (gayageum) among the low motivation group.

title: Music and the cline of Malayness: sounds of egalitarianism and ranking
summary: The cline of Malayness as exhibited in Sumatra and the Malay Peninsula extends through tribal-Malay, rakyat-Malay, aristocrat-Malay and modern urban-Malay. As a consequence of the manner in which Malay states came into being, this cline exhibits an increasing elaboration of the cultural expression of transition and transitivity. This is manifested in the different manners of musical performance favoured in the various Malay populations. In turn, these differences are paralleled closely in such other areas of Malay cultural expression as: social personality, cooking & eating, dance, religion, grammar & lexicon. Fifteen illustrative audio examples are available on the Soundcloud.com website through links given in the footnotes, where links to other cited online audio examples are also provided.

title: Malay art music composers and performers of Tanjungpinang and Pulau Penyengat
summary: This chapter was stimulated by the new music (kreasi baru) that the author heard at the 2011 Gawai/Lomba Seni in Tanjungpinang and at later performances and rehearsals on Pulau Penyengat and in Batam Centre, all in Kepulauan Riau (Kepri) province, Indonesia. Through interviews with the composers, the author has sought to uncover their specifically musical background and artistic aims against the background of the more ‘traditional’ Malay music-making still widely followed in the Bentan area. The author’s ten associated video and audio examples are available through links given in the footnotes, where links to other cited online audio examples are also provided.

title: Weltmusik
Reactions to change: Australian attitudes towards the ongoing editorial metamorphosis of the Suzuki Violin Method repertoire.
summary: This paper presents findings from a recent study into the editorial practices of pedagogue and violinist Shinichi Suzuki, and the author’s ongoing participant-observer research into preferences in repertoire and edition choice within the Suzuki Method community. It considers the apparent shift in editorial thinking and values from the widely-known and used Suzuki Violin Method repertoire books compiled, edited and revised by Shinichi Suzuki from the 1940s to the 1970s, with the major contemporary re-editing of the repertoire commenced in 2007 by the International Suzuki Association Violin Committee. The 19th century influences and apparent sympathy of Suzuki’s own early editorial practices with what scholar James Grier identifies as an interpretative edition approach, is contrasted with the Historically Informed Performance influenced aims of the current revisions initiated by Suzuki and carried out by the Violin Committee. The reaction amongst teachers and students to the apparent changes, is discussed in relation to an Australia-wide survey of Suzuki Method violin teachers.

title: Sangeet Natak Vol XLII N°1 2008.1.pdf

title: Current World Music in Music Education and its Influence on Global Cultural Diplomacy -- Directed Research at USC
summary: The specific subject matter for this directed research stems from my passion for bringing current music from around the world to secondary music education in groundbreaking ways through my innovative startup, PlayTheGroove. PlayTheGroove encompasses methodological approaches on the continuum between playing-by-ear (aural learning) and reading music. We created an adaptable framework for addressing the needs and goals of music teachers (classroom and private) and aspiring students. PlayTheGroove's results-driven framework, proven methodologies, and expanding resources for disseminating world music to classrooms, enable the profound cultural transference that can occur through being immersed in music-making. In this way, PlayTheGroove connects discussions about World Music in Music Education with the Influence on Global Cultural Diplomacy component. Cultural diplomacy is the core subject and focus area of this directed research, and I will include a few thoughts on this issue based on my findings and how they relate to PlayTheGroove. All aspects of this research, and my USC schooling, are focused on direct application to PlayTheGroove and further development of a framework to bring world musics into context with music education communities and structures, as well as supporting mutual understanding between peoples of different regions, states, and countries. Thus, PlayTheGroove spans local cultural understanding as well as global. According to Wikipedia, Cultural diplomacy is a type of public diplomacy and soft power that includes the "exchange of ideas, information, art and other aspects of culture among nations and their peoples in order to foster mutual understanding." The purpose of cultural diplomacy is for the people of a foreign nation to develop an understanding of the nation's ideals and institutions in an effort to build broad support for economic and political goals. In essence "cultural diplomacy reveals the soul of a nation," which in turn creates influence. Though often overlooked, cultural diplomacy can and does play an important role in achieving national security aims.

title: Covering Mandarin Popular Songs in Japan and Taiwan
summary: Shanghai was once the centre of Mandarin popular song and record production in Republican China, as well as a base where local and foreign musicians, singers and songwriters gathered. Through the flourishing entertainment industry and the rising new media, such as gramophone recordings, radio broadcastings and sound films, in the 1930s and 1940s musical products created in this city were distributed not only within this metropolis, but also to various regions of the country. Whereas Mandarin popular songs were rarely covered in their homeland by different singers, a few of those songs actually travelled beyond the border and were re-recorded by other artists in Japan or Taiwan. The cover versions were all reinterpreted quite differently in terms of singing styles and instrumentations from their originals. Viewing a song as a human body, we can see its skeleton formed by the melody and lyrics at the stage of composition, then its flesh added after the work of arrangement and finally its soul gained when performed. This paper takes two well-known Mandarin film songs, 'Wandering Songstress' (Tianya genü) and 'Fisherman's Song' (Yuguang qu), as main examples to explore how Chinese songs would be reborn in Japan or Taiwan with new lyrics, arrangements and performing styles. Furthermore, by tracking the transnational flow of songs, the paper also looks into how record industry in Shanghai and those in Japan and Taiwan were connected through musical expertise and products.

title: GuiHANGtar: Rooted in Tradition, Molded by Innovation

title: Review of A Theory for All Music: Problems and Solutions in the Analysis of non-Western Forms, Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism 43/3 (1985): 321-27
Javanese Pelog Tunings Reconsidered: Yearbook of the International Folk Music Council, Vol. 10 (1978), pp. 69-82
summary: Previous studies of Javanese pélog tunings (by Murray Barbour, Manfred Bukofzer, Alexander Ellis, Max Harrell, Mantle Hood, Jaap Kunst, J.P.N. Land, Donald Lentz, and Kathleen Schlesinger) are evaluated. The author's thesis that pélog tunings are closest to a division of the octave into nine equal parts is tested against other theories using data published by Wasisto Surjodiningrat. The nine-tone hypothesis proves to give the best approximation to the tunings. Possible objections to the approach are discussed, as are implications for the analysis of pieces in pélog.

title: outline and explanations
